unnormalised: When it comes to medications, dosages are critically dependent on units of weight and volume. unnormalised: Lab tests also rely heavily on accurate measurement. Blood glucose levels, for example, are often reported in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) in India, though some labs may use millimoles per liter (mmol/L). Similarly, hemoglobin levels are measured in grams per deciliter (g/dL). These values are crucial for diagnosing conditions such as diabetes and anemia. Kidney function tests, like creatinine levels, also depend on these standardized units.

unnormalised: Furthermore, diagnostic imaging techniques such as X-rays, CT scans, and MRIs also involve measurements, though indirectly. Radiation exposure is measured in millisieverts (mSv), and guidelines dictate safe limits to minimize patient risk. Ultrasound images use frequencies measured in megahertz (MHz), which determine the resolution and penetration depth. Knowing these units helps in understanding the associated risks and benefits.

unnormalised: Anthropometric measurements are also fundamental in healthcare. A patient's height is typically recorded in centimeters (cm) or meters (m), while weight is measured in kilograms (kg). Body Mass Index (BMI), calculated from height and weight, is a widely used indicator of healthy weight ranges, particularly in assessing metabolic health and risks of conditions such as obesity. For infants, length is measured in centimeters as well, helping track their development.

unnormalised: Blood pressure readings are given in millimeters of mercury (mmHg), with the systolic pressure (pressure when the heart beats) and diastolic pressure (pressure when the heart rests) expressed as two separate values. For instance, a reading of 120/80 mmHg is considered normal for many adults. Variations from this range could indicate hypertension or hypotension, requiring further investigation.
